text:
> Yeah, I think packages like StatsKit.jl are the solution here. Just a wrapper package that reexports everything so that whatever environment you’re in, you do ] add StatsKit thé using StatsKit and boom , done.
Wrapper packages are kinda tricky/non-ideal for a few reasons:

- Every breaking change for a dependency is effectively also a breaking change for the wrapper package.  Versioning it becomes tricky.

- It becomes awkward to find documentation for functions. You need to find out the actual package where the function came from and then look up the docs for that package anyway. At that point, might have been better to just imported the actual package.

- It increases package load time since you unconditionally load all the packages in the wrapper package. It seems unlikely that you would use exactly all of the packages in there.

text:
I agree with all of those points, which is why I think personal wrappers for projects is a better way to go (and if you use the same functionality across multiple projects, making this wrapper a personal package is trivially easy). A couple of counter points though:

• Hopefully as more packages stabilize, breaking changes won't be as frequent, lowering the burden of breakages.
• Docstrings are still attached to functions. The point still stands since a lot of documentation isn't in docstrings. I wonder how hard it would be to automatically add links to doc pages in docstrings :thinking_face: 
• If you're actually using all or most of the packages, you'd incur that wait time anyway, and and the convenience / cleanliness of code may be worth the trade-off.
